heading: unlocking dna's double helix
subheading: harvard researchers catch the first snapshot of an enzyme that facilitates dna replication. they hope to find out how the little devil does its stuff. by kristen philipkoski.
author: wired news report
text: for the first time, researchers have been able to see the structure that unwinds the dna double helix. the structure is a doughnut-shaped enzyme critical to dna replication. scientists at harvard have created an atomic resolution image to look at the enzyme, called a helicase. the research appears in the 15 october issue of the scientific journal cell.if the researchers can find out how the helicase works, "we'll understand how dna gets replicated," said michael sawaya, a postdoctoral fellow in biological chemistry and molecular pharmacology at harvard."in order for a person to pass their genes on to their children, the gene code has to be copied," sawaya said."there is a machine made of several components [that makes this happen], and a lot of chemical reactions have to go on. the one that starts the machine running is the helicase," he said. "it makes the dna available to the other enzymes that copy it."the discovery could lead to disease therapies."eventually [helicases] could be used for designing anti-cancer drugs because we know that cancer is caused by mutations that occur during the replication progress," sawaya said.the harvard researchers used a virus called bacteriophage t7 to develop a model of human dna, which allowed them to see how the helicase unwinds the twisted pair."this is beautiful work, obviously," said dr. peter kollman, a professor of chemistry and pharmacological chemistry, at the university of california at san francisco, who works with modeling proteins. "they've solved a structure of a very important protein that opens up dna."in humans, the doughnut-shaped group of proteins unwinds the dna in the same way to reveal its genetic letters and facilitate dna replication.the scientists used x-ray crystallography -- a method of adding hydrogen to an atom to crystallize it so that it can be x-rayed -- to create the model. the image shows six of the structures that resemble a ring of bread buns."that kind of x-ray crystallography is the most powerful technology for determining the structure of molecules," kollman said.scientists know next to nothing about how these helicases slip dna strands through themselves to perform their untwisting, even though they are recognized as a fundamental molecular machine of the cell, according to tom ellenberger, associate professor of biological chemistry and molecular pharmacology at harvard.helicases are interesting to researchers because they are molecular motors, similar to the structures that function to contract a muscle.scientists don't know how the helicase converts energy into motion. the harvard researchers' image gives the scientists a chance at solving the mystery.when the helicase travels down a strand of dna, it breaks through the connections, called watson-crick bonds, joining the double strand together. it also harnesses enough energy to significantly change its shape, and grab and let go of dna.the ring-shaped helicase threads one strand of dna through its central hole and trucks through 300 paired nucleotides per second while shoving the other strand out of the way.in the past, researchers have tried to stop the helicase by binding proteins on the dna's back, but it had enough energy to knock them off and force its way through.while this particular helicase pries apart the dna strands to facilitate replication, genetic sequencing data suggests there are hundreds of different helicases in the human genome. other types help with dna repair, transcription, and other jobs. scientists believe the helicases most likely come into play whenever dna needs to open up temporarily.this is one piece of a larger puzzle -- the researchers' ultimate goal is to solve the entire dna copying process. to finish the job, the harvard scientists will collaborate with researchers at oxford university who have also been studying dna replication.the two labs which were once competitors have now decided to collaborate."they asked for help to solve the larger fragment using the data of the model that i made, and they in turn agreed to give us coordinates for a larger model," sawaya said. "that will help us solve the whole molecule."
